issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: There are a bunch of tests related to TestMiniTezCliDriver which gives ordering issues when run on Centos/Windows/OSX

comments.body:
I'm +1 on this patch, since what it's doing is essentially making sure that ordering issues do not cause a problem. Ultimately, we should take on a task to make sure that our test cases do not care about order if marked with some set variable, and use that(like we sometimes do for os version or hadoop version), since introducing blanket order-by actually changes the clause we might be testing elsewhere. Tagging [~ashutoshc] to bring this notion to his attention.

For this patch, though, we should limit the scope of this, and get it in.

ATTACHMENT ID: 12730256 - PreCommit-HIVE-TRUNK-Build

Actually, I should have seen this on my review earlier - changes to .q files would result in changes to .out files, if only from the query being different. Also, given that it introduces a sort ordering, any explain will be different in the .out. Could you please regen your patch including all the .out changes?

[~sushanth] you are thinking in right direction, only that it already exists : )
Comment directive {{-- SORT_QUERY_RESULTS}} is invented for this exact used case. Please use that instead of adding order by in queries. If anything else (ie other than query result set) is order sensitive, then use {{--SORT_BEFORE_DIFF}}

Awesome! That is good news. :)

[~hsubramaniyan], could you use that instead?
Note that the sort directive will not work for queries that involve limit. There is at least one such query in this case. But for other queries, the sort directive would be better.
I have not verified in code, but thats my understanding too. Only once in q file should be sufficient to cover for all queries in it.

Hi Hari,

Apologies for the late reply - having looked at all the .q files now, I'm +1 on it. However, I'm afraid I took too long to review this, and this now requires a rebase to update to latest. When applying this patch now, I get the following:

{noformat}

Updating the .q files after rebase.

Thanks
Hari
